subject: 515a 4/21 Update: Soyuz undocks from station
body:
515a 4/21 Update: Soyuz undocks from station



=================================

CBS NEWS Coverage of Breaking Space News
Last Updated: 05:15 a.m., 04/21/07 (all times Eastern)

By William Harwood
CBS News Space Consultant

Changes and additions:

   04/20/07 (03:30 p.m.): Station crew prepares for Saturday landing
   04/21/07 (05:15 a.m.): Soyuz TMA-9 undocks from space station

=================================

05:15 a.m., 04/21/07, Update: Soyuz TMA-9 undocks from space station

Departing space station commander Mike Lopez-Alegria, Soyuz commander Mikhail Tyurin and American businessman Charles Simonyi undocked from the international space station's Zvezda command module at 5:11 a.m. EDT today, setting the stage for landing in Kazakhstan around 8:30 a.m..

"Thank you very much for the hospitality. I enjoyed working here and working with the excellent crews and commanders," Simonyi said during a farewell ceremony erlier this morning. "I'm looking forward to the return flight. It is a bittersweet moment for all of us. We are very sad leaving the station but at the same time looking forward to continuing our work on Earth."

If all goes well, the Soyuz TMA-9 spacecraft will fire its braking rockets at 7:42:30 a.m. for four minutes and 18 seconds, slowing the craft's 5-mile-per-second velocity by about 258 mph. That's just enough to drop the craft into the atmosphere on a trajectory leading to a landing zone in Kazakhstan where Russian recovery forces will be standing by to greet the returning spacemen.

Here is a timeline of today's events (in EDT):

EDT...........EVENT

05:11:30 AM - Physical separation (dV: 0.27 mph)
05:14:30 AM - Soyuz separation burn No. 1 (15-second burn; velocity change: 1.45 mph)
05:16:30 AM - Space station attitude control re-enabled

07:42:30 AM - Deorbit ignition (planned velocity change: 257.7 mph)
07:46:48 AM - Deorbit burn complete

08:05:37 AM - Soyuz TMA-9 module separation
08:08:29 AM - Soyuz descent module hits the discernible atmosphere at 400,000 feet
08:10:03 AM - Entry guidance begins
08:14:14 AM - Maximum deceleration
08:16:33 AM - Parachute deploy command
08:30:34 AM - Landing
10:23:00 AM - Sunset at landing site
